page.title: 13LANDSCAPE
page.content: Whittington is an Anglo-Saxon word.It was first spelt HWITINGTUN which means the farm belonging to HWIT.The word later became WHIT - hence WHITTINGTON. THE COUNTY GALLOWS were in Whittington on the site of 4 Whittington Rd. and the Hangman's coach used to stand in Walker's Lane.It is said that ghosts of of hanged victims have been seen near this site.CROOKBARROW HILL-(known as Whittington Tump) is oval and about six acres.X-rays have shown that it is not a burial ground as was once thought.Roman coins have been found in the field.The VILLAGE SCHOOL, this church of England school was built in 1858,modernised in 1955,and it still exists because I am a pupil there.The village of Whittington has a church,a public house and a population of some people.
